data.text:
Unfortunately you made a cardinal error that is not uncommon among the inexperienced and you now have a damaged frame. Not all bike frames are suitable for a bike stand that clamps around the chainstays !!!!! I am often asked to install such stands and will frankly advise the enquirer whether their bike is suitable or not. A little look on the Surly website would have quickly led to this page which explains clearly and frankly:- https://surlybikes.com/info_hole/spew/kickstands_on_long_haul_truckers A long haul trucker is one of the finest riding touring frames in the World and typical of it's type there is no way a clamp on stand should have ever been contemplated for that design of frame. The same caveat applies to many other fine frames. I have an older 3-speed Raleigh upon which I have installed a clamp on stand - no problem - that is an example of a hefty thick-wall tubed utility frame. The lesson: DO YOUR RESEARCH or go to a competent bicycle shop when considering things like this.

data.text: Reasons to not use traditional kickstand on a loaded tour bike: The center of gravity is too low. Literally at the lowest point of the frame. All the weight you are carrying is much higher and is leaning to one side adding more pressure and stress. Every little twist, gust of wind, or the wrong touch, and the bike goes down. Eventually either the kick stand breaks or the frame gets messed up. Solution: get a retractable hiking pole to use as a kickstand. Set the stick to reach the seat. The higher the contact point, the higher the center of mass moves, the more stable your bike will be. Put the hiking pole hand loop through the seat for extra security so it can't slip or slide. Bike will never fall again or break. For added security, lock the breaks of both wheels by wrapping a rubber band round the handbrake and the handlebar. This keeps bike from micro movements that will cause to the bike to fall. *Hiking pole can be used for as many things as you are creative but more importantly, to keep the chasing dog at bay. You could buy the click-stand (Google it). It's the same idea but for an UL solution. It works great for small light tours. I am on 2nd tour around the world. I currently have 42kg (bike + everything before food and water). In the beginning of my 1st tour I broke 2 click-stands before I switched to a hiking pole and never had problems since.
